channel.title: Going Linux
channel.description:
Been using windows since 95, fuckin know anything windows like the back of my hand, want a challenge in the computer world.
About a year ago i tried out linux for 10 minutes, downloaded OpenSuSe i think it was, installed it and it just didn't seem like i installed it right? (screen was half the size, couldent find where to change res) bunch of other stuff.
People say i should start off with ubuntu, which i may do once i get uncapped so i can download it.
I will be using Linux for everything such as programming , music, irc, browsing etc. Except gaming (Trying to brighten my computer knowledge, nothing else i can learn more until i make the jump to linux)
Will be keeping XP as well for when i game.
Also is drivers and shit gonna be easy to set up? like, i got a mobo which only has windows drivers, how will i get all that shit to support with linux? same goes with video card, external hard drive, is there usb 2.0?

item.title: Going Linux
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“ThAt0n36Uy, post:21, topic:273542”][quote author=T4_ link=topic=361461.msg2755488#msg2755488 date=1240169377]

I like how people keep pointing out they’ve been using Windows since '95. When there were drastically fewer generations of it compared to Linux. Wow uh(not including earlier OSes, and variants i.e: 1.0, ME, etc.), '95, '98, Xp, Vista, 7. HUGE jump there, especially since each generation was radically different from the next.

Windows 3.1x -> Windows 98 -> Windows XP -> Ubuntu -> SuSE -> Fedora
and some others in between.
[/quote]

I have no idea what point you were trying to make, but OK.[/quote]
Just input. Not an argument.

Read full topic

item.title: Going Linux
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“runescape3dude, post:13, topic:273542”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=361461.msg2749251#msg2749251 date=1239819716]
You need to get used to the linux way of installing things. You don’t google, download and install like on windows. It is much easier, you simply open your package manager (on ubuntu, I think it comes with synaptic) and search and click install on whatever you want. xchat is what I recommend for IRC, the best music player I’ve ever used is Amarok, and on all Operating Systems VLC is the way to go for video.

As to your video card, open the restricted driver manager and enable the nvidia drivers (that get’s you the proprietary driver from nvidia.com) and in synaptic install the nvidia-xconfig or nvidia-settings and use that to adjust anything you want about your graphics card.

Any other questions, post here.
[/quote]

I’m a retard, so I use the root account on my computer. Which means I can’t use VLC right. I ended up getting smplayer for my computer, which seems to be a fairly decent player.[/quote]

Why would you do that? Just make a real account and use it, running everything as root simply doesn’t make any sense.

Read full topic

item.title: Going Linux
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:17, topic:273542”][quote author=T4_ link=topic=361461.msg2752520#msg2752520 date=1240000333]

Also is drivers and shit gonna be easy to set up? like, i got a mobo which only has windows drivers, how will i get all that shit to support with linux? same goes with video card, external hard drive, is there usb 2.0?

There is USB 2.0, and I wouldn’t be surprised if Linux had USB 3.0 before Windows does. Ubuntu does a great job of automounting almost all the USB devices I’ve used with it.

Already does: The Linux Kernel supports USB 3.0 as of version 2.6.30.

@xEnt: nvidia has pretty good binary drivers available for linux, and I guess alsa will support the sound card as well.

Don’t EVER go with ATI if it’s a Linux machine. Also, USB 3.0 is supported as aforementioned; you see, Linux supports the good hardware right away. Only reason why some drivers are hard is due to copyright issues.
[/quote]Actually i get better performance on linux than windows with my sapphire hd 4850 in xfire[/quote]

Oh yes, but that is because that is an OpenGL card; besides, I did not state the performance was lower, just finding drivers is sometimes cumbersome.

Read full topic

item.title: Going Linux
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

[quote=“xEnt, post:7, topic:273542”]k guys im on ubuntu right now, and have been for the last half hour. I go download mirc, fails, i go download xchat, said only allows fedora linux? i go download winamp and thats fuckin windows too.

Suggest me a good music player, video player, irc client, and whatever else is essential? (linux only)[/quote]
Installing apps on Ubuntu is as easy as sudo apt-get install

Xchat = sudo apt-get install xchat

Also, mIRC is Windows-only…

Read full topic

item.title: Going Linux
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“xEnt, post:7, topic:273542”]k guys im on ubuntu right now, and have been for the last half hour. I go download mirc, fails, i go download xchat, said only allows fedora linux? i go download winamp and thats fuckin windows too.

Suggest me a good music player, video player, irc client, and whatever else is essential? (linux only)[/quote]

XMMS is pretty much Winamp Classic, albeit slightly “buggy”, Amaorak is good from what I hear.

As already mentioned, there are easier ways of getting programs than using google(but it is an option, took me forever to find the mp3 plugin for XMMS on Fedora, and 5 mins or so on google and I found it).

Read full topic

item.title: Going Linux
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:11, topic:273542”]You need to get used to the linux way of installing things. You don’t google, download and install like on windows. It is much easier, you simply open your package manager (on ubuntu, I think it comes with synaptic) and search and click install on whatever you want. xchat is what I recommend for IRC, the best music player I’ve ever used is Amarok, and on all Operating Systems VLC is the way to go for video.

As to your video card, open the restricted driver manager and enable the nvidia drivers (that get’s you the proprietary driver from nvidia.com) and in synaptic install the nvidia-xconfig or nvidia-settings and use that to adjust anything you want about your graphics card.

Any other questions, post here.[/quote]

I’m a retard, so I use the root account on my computer. Which means I can’t use VLC right. I ended up getting smplayer for my computer, which seems to be a fairly decent player.

Read full topic

item.title: Going Linux
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

use " nvidia-xconfig --add-argb-glx-visuals --composite " rather than just nvidia-xconfig.

Read full topic

You need to get used to the linux way of installing things. You don’t google, download and install like on windows. It is much easier, you simply open your package manager (on ubuntu, I think it comes with synaptic) and search and click install on whatever you want. xchat is what I recommend for IRC, the best music player I’ve ever used is Amarok, and on all Operating Systems VLC is the way to go for video.

As to your video card, open the restricted driver manager and enable the nvidia drivers (that get’s you the proprietary driver from nvidia.com) and in synaptic install the nvidia-xconfig or nvidia-settings and use that to adjust anything you want about your graphics card.

item.title: Going Linux
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“xEnt, post:9, topic:273542”]Spent an hour on it, couldent get the refresh rate from 60 to 85 hz, and ended up burning my eyes too much, uncomfortable programs (media player was shit and had to actually download codecs to play mp3?), got xchat and that was a lump of shit. The only thing i did enjoy was the double desktops, and sliding programs across. Whats with the password request popping up everytime u wanna do somethin? anyway im back on windows and happy.[/quote]Refresh rate is cus you prolly didn’t install the proprietary nvidia drivers, xmms is a great media player (all codecs already there), and xchat is a personal preference, i enjoy it rather much because it’s not bloated.

Read full topic

item.title: Going Linux
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

Sounds awesome, 8800GT… most popular video card, must have drivers for that. My mobo is a asus IP35-P mobo, the main thing i do want is my integrated high def audio working, without that will piss me off.

Read full topic

item.title: Going Linux
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

xEnt:

Also is drivers and shit gonna be easy to set up? like, i got a mobo which only has windows drivers, how will i get all that shit to support with linux? same goes with video card, external hard drive, is there usb 2.0?

Tell us what kind of hardware…Chances are it will just work (you may need to click a button to get hardware accelerated 3d graphics). There is USB 2.0, and I wouldn’t be surprised if Linux had USB 3.0 before Windows does. Ubuntu does a great job of automounting almost all the USB devices I’ve used with it.

Read full topic

item.title: Going Linux
item.dc:creator: @Creme_de_la_Creme Creme de la Creme
item.description:
@Creme_de_la_Creme wrote:

I’m still slowly making the switch from windows to linux (I’ve been using it since 95 too). I just installed ubuntu and xp as a dual boot and use either depending on what I’m doing.

It’s been harder to get drivers for linux and emulate the same sort of things XP has that I couldn’t live without, but sometimes it’s better. My webcam no longer works on xp with the official driver but I got it working within minutes using easycam on ubuntu. Same goes for my printer - I didn’t even need to search for a driver on ubuntu. It also worked perfectly with my video card straight off, XP needed the dell driver disc.

As with windows, external hard disks will function without having to reformat but sometimes drive mounting can be a bit weird if you’re not used to it.

I’m by no means a linux expert but find it much better for productive tasks, and XP for everything else like gaming, os dependant software and a familiar msn ui.

Read full topic

item.title: Going Linux
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

xEnt:

Will be keeping XP as well for when i game.

That is a good idea but you would be suprised how many games work perfectly under wine. CS:Source, WoW, Cod 4 are just some games that work well.
Arch Linux is probably the best distro to start off with if you want a “challenge”. Ubuntu is ok if you like/can run Vista but as Moparisthebest said the community is full of retards.

Read full topic

item.title: Going Linux
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

Been using windows since 95, fuckin know anything windows like the back of my hand, want a challenge in the computer world.

About a year ago i tried out linux for 10 minutes, downloaded OpenSuSe i think it was, installed it and it just didn’t seem like i installed it right? (screen was half the size, couldent find where to change res) bunch of other stuff.

People say i should start off with ubuntu, which i may do once i get uncapped so i can download it.

I will be using Linux for everything such as programming , music, irc, browsing etc. Except gaming (Trying to brighten my computer knowledge, nothing else i can learn more until i make the jump to linux)

Will be keeping XP as well for when i game.

Also is drivers and shit gonna be easy to set up? like, i got a mobo which only has windows drivers, how will i get all that shit to support with linux? same goes with video card, external hard drive, is there usb 2.0?

Read full topic
